results.creator_credit: Krystal Webb, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My life as I live it
results.creator_credit: Kit Guyatt, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey’s first film, MY SURVIVAL AS AN ABORIGINAL (1978), is now a classic. It introduced us to the life of her family and her community in far northwest New South Wales. Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. This portrait of an Aboriginal community working towards self-determination is a testament to Essie’s life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kit Guyatt, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Australian Film Commission
results.description: Essie Coffey’s first film, MY SURVIVAL AS AN ABORIGINAL (1978), is now a classic. It introduced us to the life of her family and her community in far northwest New South Wales. Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. description_for_label: Essie Coffey’s first film, MY SURVIVAL AS AN ABORIGINAL (1978), is now a classic. It introduced us to the life of her family and her community in far northwest New South Wales. Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. This portrait of an Aboriginal community working towards self-determination is a testament to Essie’s life.

results.title: My survival as an Aboriginal
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions
results.brief_description: After being forced from their tribal grounds, the Murrowarri were dumped onto a tiny reserve on the fringe of a white town. In this film Essie Coffey, black activist and musician, shows the conflicts of living as an Aboriginal under white domination. This film is part of her effort to make her community proud of their black identity while struggling to survive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions

results.title: Hal Porter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A witty, biting commentary about life and an author’s place in it. Hal Porter reminisces about teaching, acting, producing for the theatre, and his life in Melbourne, Bairnsdale and Japan.

results.title: Christina Stead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
In the only filmed interview with one of Australia’s most popular and respected novelists, Christina Stead is both challenging and revealing.

results.title: Marjorie Barnard
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Historical novelist, Marjorie Barnard recalls priceless memories of fellow writers who “peopled her world”, including Xavier Herbert, Vance and Nettie Palmer and Frank Dalby Davison.

results.title: Gwen Harwood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A charming film of poet Gwen Harwood speaking at her home in Tasmania about her work in poetry and her love for music and opera.

results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

results.title: Kylie Tennant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Kylie Tennant drew her inspiration from people she knew, and her exuberant interview is in itself a valuable piece of Australian social history.
